title: 107_hr120
content: The "Social Security and Medicare Lock-box Act of 2001" aims to prioritize the solvency of social security and Medicare by prohibiting the use of their surpluses for any other purpose until legislation is passed to extend their trust funds' solvency. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to reserve surpluses until Social Security and Medicare solvency legislation is enacted, prohibiting the use of surpluses for any other purpose until certifications are obtained. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to reserve surpluses until Social Security and Medicare solvency legislation is enacted, prohibiting the use of surpluses for any other purpose until certifications are obtained. The baseline budget surplus is defined as the sum of on- and off-budget surpluses in the most recent baseline budget projections made by the Congressional Budget Office. The term 'baseline budget projection' refers to the projection of current year levels of outlays, receipts, and surplus or deficit into the budget year and future years. It includes both on-budget and off-budget outlays and receipts, with discretionary appropriations subject to statutory limits. A portion of the baseline budget surpluses is used if there is any net reduction in revenues in current legislation affecting revenues. For the purposes of this subsection, a portion of the baseline budget surpluses is used if there is any net reduction in revenues in current legislation affecting revenues, direct spending, or discretionary outlays. The bill requires certifications of social security and Medicare solvency by the Board of Trustees to ensure actuarial balance for specific periods. The bill amends the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 to require a supermajority for certain provisions related to the Hospital Insurance Trust Fund's actuarial balance. SEC. 4. EFFECTIVE DATE. This Act will be effective upon enactment and only apply to fiscal year 2001 and beyond.
